```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, error = TRUE)
library(tidyverse)
```
# Monday

```{r}
mendota = read_csv("../data/lake-mendota-winters-2025.csv")
```

We will use the in-built tidyverse dataset called `mpg`.

```{r}
# step 1: stepping up the canvas

ggplot()
```

```{r}
#step 2: specify the data

ggplot(data = mpg)
```

```{r}
#step 3: specify the mappings

ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = cty, y = hwy))
```

```{r}
#step 4: specify the type of plot

ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(cty, hwy)) + 
  geom_point(col = "red") +
  geom_line()
```

# Wednesday

```{r}
# adding color to the points depoending on the vehicles cylinder

ggplot(mpg, mapping = aes(cty, hwy, col = as.factor(cyl))) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_line()
```

# variable vs constant aesthetic

```{r}
ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(cty, hwy)) + 
  geom_point(col = "red") +
  geom_line()

ggplot(mpg, mapping = aes(cty, hwy, col = as.factor(cyl))) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_line()
```

# global vs local aesthetic

```{r}
ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(cty, hwy)) + 
  geom_point(col = "red") + # local aesthetic because the color is applied to only the points and not the lines
  geom_line()

ggplot(mpg, mapping = aes(cty, hwy, col = as.factor(cyl))) +# global aethetic because the color gets applied to both the points and lines
  geom_point() +
  geom_line()
```

```{r}
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = mpg, mapping = aes(cty, hwy), col = "red") +
  geom_line()
```

```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = cty, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point(color = "purple", size = 4)
```

# Two variable:

- geom_point()
- geom_line()
- geom_smooth(): thsi function smakes trendlines (line of best fit)

```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(cty, hwy)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()

ggplot(mpg, aes(cty, hwy)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(se = F, method = "lm")
```

- geom_col():

```{r}
ggplot(count(mpg, class), aes(class, n)) + 
  geom_col(color = "purple", fill = "yellow") # the argument fill is used for shaped plots, where the shapes have an area that can be colored 
```

ggplot(mpg, aes(cty, hwy)) +

# One- variable plot

- bar graph (this is only to make bar graph with count as the y axis)

```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(manufacturer)) +
  geom_bar()

ggplot(mpg, aes(drv)) +
  geom_bar()

ggplot(mpg, aes(y = fl)) +
  geom_bar()

ggplot(mpg, aes(displ)) +
  geom_bar()
```


- histogram (this is a graph that displays frequency of a variable (continuous) instead of count)


```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(displ)) +
  geom_histogram(bin)

ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 10, fill = "skyblue")

ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "skyblue")

ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "skyblue", boundary = 0)

ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "skyblue", center = 2.5)
```

- geom_density(): density plot: this is for making density plots for continuous variables 

```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +
  geom_density()
```

```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), binwidth = 5) +
  geom_density(col = "red") 
```

- alpha: controls the opacity of plots. The value of alpha ranges between 0 and 1.

```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), binwidth = 5, fill = "yellow", col = "orange") +
  geom_density(col = "red", fill = "pink", alpha = 0.7) 
```

- geom_boxplot(): 

```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```
